Include summary of condition at discharge.

Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

March 6, 2024

Dear ___,

I hope this letter finds you well as you prepare to return home after your recent hospitalization with us. I am writing to provide a summary of your hospital stay and the treatments you received, as well as instructions for your ongoing care and follow-up appointments.

You were admitted to our hospital on March 1, 2024, due to experiencing severe chest pain that radiated to your left arm, accompanied by shortness of breath. An immediate Electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), specifically an acute transmural myocardial infarction of the anterior wall. Following this diagnosis, a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was urgently performed on the same day, which involved the placement of a stent to restore normal blood flow.

During your stay, you received a treatment regimen that included Aspirin (325 mg daily), Clopidogrel (75 mg daily), and IV Heparin adjusted per protocol. For the management of chest pain, Nitroglycerin was administered as needed. Subsequently, you started on Metoprolol, a beta-blocker at a dose of 50 mg twice daily, alongside Lisinopril, an ACE Inhibitor at 10 mg once daily, and a statin at 40 mg once daily to manage your cholesterol levels taken from your initial lipid profile showing elevated LDL cholesterol.

Your condition stabilized progressively, as noted during daily ward rounds. By March 2nd, you reported feeling better, with no recurrent chest pain, and your troponin levels, elevated at the time of admission, began to decrease. Continued monitoring noted no complications, and by March 3rd, there was a significant improvement in your overall condition. Discharge and rehabilitation plans were subsequently discussed, leading to your preparation for discharge on March 5th.

At the time of your discharge on March 6th, 2024, your vitals were stable, with no reported symptoms of discomfort, and medications were appropriately prescribed. You have been educated on your medication regimen, including the importance of adherence to help prevent future cardiac events.

Looking forward, you have a follow-up appointment scheduled at the cardiology outpatient clinic for March 20, 2024. During this appointment, your recovery and medication management will be carefully assessed to ensure optimal post-discharge care.

Additionally, lifestyle modifications are advised to support your recovery and long-term health. We recommend adopting a heart-healthy diet low in saturated fats and sodium while increasing your intake of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. A gradual reintroduction of physical activity is encouraged, aiming to build up to at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity per week. Given the importance of smoking cessation, you are advised to cease smoking immediately, and support options such as nicotine replacement therapy and counseling are available if needed. Moreover, exploring stress management techniques like mindfulness and yoga may further contribute to your well-being.

Please maintain close communication with your healthcare providers and do not hesitate to reach out should any health concerns or questions arise during your recovery at home. We wish you a smooth and uninterrupted recuperation.

Warm regards,

Dr. ___
